3. 1 set of 3-of-a-kind and 1 set of 4-in-a-row
4. 2 sets of 4-of-a-kind
5. 1 set of 3-of-a-kind and 1 set of 5-in-a-row
6. 3 sets of 3-of-a-kind
7. 1 set of 7-in-a-row
8. 2 sets of 4-in-a-row
9. 1 set of 3-of-a-kind and 1 set 0f 6-in-a-row
10. 2 sets of 5-of-a-kind
11. 1 set of 9-in-a-row

Points:
Jokers and 2's (2 are jokers too): 20 points
Aces: 15 points
10, J, Q, K: 10 points
3-9: 5 points

Name: Thieves Den: Wizard's Tower Promo Card
Description:
This promo provides a new location card to the game.

This promo comes with two copies of the location card and a rules card. In a 2-player game, only use the card with the moon icon. In games with 3+ players, use both cards.

The location's ability is: pay 1 thief to gain two wild treasures.

This card introduces a new location type--Wild location. This location can represent any of the other five location types. The location type chosen is selected at the end of the game.

This promo was available in Game Trade Magazine #234 (August 2019).

Name: GameRox
Description:
Be the first player to finish all five GameRox levels. Each level involves tossing and catching different combinations of GameRox. Each player takes five GameRox in on hand, tosses them in to the air, and tries to catch as many as possible on the back of the same hand. Whoever catches the most goes first.

Players are only allowed to toss, pick up, nudge, and catch GameRox with one hand at a time. After you have tossed the GameRox into the air, you are allowed to nudge any GameRox in the play area closer together using the same hand as long as you continue catching the tossed GameRox.

Level 1: Cast your GameRox over the play area. Pick and throw one GameRox into the air. Pick up a second GameRox from the play surface, then catch the tossed GameRox. If you succeed, keep tossing and picking up a single GameRox until you have picked up all four GameRox. You can set one GameRox aside after picking it up. If you drop a GameRox, it’s the next player’s turn. Once you succeed in picking up all four GameRox, move to Level 2.

Level 2: Pick up two at a time.

Level 3: Pick up three or one at a time.

Level 4: Pick up four at a time.

Level 5: Put all five GameRox in the palms of your hands. Toss them into the air and try to catch all five on the backs of your hands. Then, with the GameRox, still on the back of your hands, toss the GameRox into the air again and catch all five in the palms of your hands.

Redo Points
The points on the flat side of the GameRox are Redo Points. Each time you cast your GameRox, add up the numbers that land face up. You can spend 5 Redo Points to redo a toss if you drop a GameRox, or 20 Redo Points to skip an entire level.

—description from the designer

Name: Fuse
Description:
In Fuse, players alternate turns entering their discs into the board, eventually pushing other discs along the way, with the goal of creating the biggest group of their colour.

Fuse is a derivative of Feed the ducks by the same designer, that adds up to the family of other ‘push/attract games’ such as Avverso (Henrik Morast) or Momentum (Phil Leduc). It also uses the piece-entering mechanism of games like 9tka (Adam KaÅ‚uÅ¼a).

EQUIPMENT

12 ‘ice’ discs, 12 black discs, board, carrying case, 2 small blue discs (king indicators).

GAMEPLAY (please refer to rulebook for detailed rules)

Players alternate turns entering one of the perimetral discs into the 6x6 inner area of the board. One or more discs may be pushed forward as a result.

The game ends when both players pass in succession. The player with the largest group of connected discs of her color wins the game.

ADVANCED GAME MODES:

Omega Scoring: The same score as in the game OMEGA (by the same designer) is applied.

Kings mode: One or two pieces per player (indicated by a blue disc on top) are worth 2 points.

-description from designer

Name: Tank Chess: Central Square
Description:
This expansion gives an abstract game a new suit. Instead of black and white squares with dark shapes as obstacles, the board shows city streets and you also receive the buildings to assemble, which play the role of the obstacles. The 3D printed elements (trees, columns) are also a part of the set and assembling the buildings is fun on its own.

—description from the designer

Name: Fali Ti 1 Papir
Description:
An educational game about business paperwork.

The goal of the game is to found a company. Players roll dice move their pieces on a path, which contains fields with questions about business and economy. Correct answers allow players to go forward. The winner is the player who first reaches the end of the path.

By playing the game, players learn how to solve paperwork issues and how to run a business.

—user summary
